Table 1 The pseudo code of the TBKSFA based fault detection method. Algorithm 1. The TBKSFA based fault detection for the AHU system Input: The three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) and the test sample x te Procedure: 1. Unfold the dataset X ( I × J × K ) along the batch-wise direction to obtain the two-way matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) . 2. Normalize the matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) according to (9) and then rearrange it into a new training matrix X ( IK × J ) along the variable-wise direction. 3. Determine a pseudo time series matrix T k ( 2 Il × J ) of the time slice matrix X k ( I × J ) according to (10), then reconstruct a pseudo time series matrix T ( 2 Il × J ) of the training matrix X ( I × J ) according to (11). 4. Build the TBKSFA model in the high-dimensional linear space using (14) and (15), then with the aid of kernel trick, derive the kernel model of TBKSFA according to (16). 5. Solve the generalized eigenvalue decomposition problem given in (17) to achieve the loading matrix A p , where the number of retained generalized eigenvectors p is determined according to (18). 6. Extract slow features of the training dataset to compute the statistics T 2 and SPE , and employ the KDE algorithm to calculate their threshold values. 7. Normalize the test sample x te utilizing the training dataset, then compute the test kernel vector k te with the help of kernel trick. 8. Figure out the values of statistics T 2 and SPE for test kernel vector k te using (19) and (20), then compare them with the respective threshold values. 9. If at least one of the two threshold values is exceeded, a fault is detected, then jump to the KDSFA based fault diagnosis method; otherwise, there is no abnormal behavior, then return to step 7. Output: The operating status of the AHU system. Table 2 The pseudo code of the KDSFA based fault diagnosis method. Algorithm 2. The KDSFA based fault pattern nonlinear identification for the AHU system Input: The three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) , the collected n s fault samples and the historical fault dataset H . Procedure: 1. Establish the fault snapshot dataset S using the collected n s fault samples, and normalize it on the ground of the training dataset. 2. Compute the intra-class temporal variance in the dataset S using (21), and calculate the average matrix of the dataset X ( I × J × K ) to obtain the average training dataset X ∼ according to (25) and (24). 3. Build the intra-class SFA model in the high-dimensional linear space given in (26), then with the help of kernel trick, derive the corresponding kernel model according to (27). 4. Establish an inter-class pseudo time series t b ( i ) of the i -th sample x S ( i ) utilizing (29), then construct the inter-class pseudo time series T b ( 2 n s p × J ) of the datasets S and X ∼ according to (30). 5. Build the inter-class separability optimization in the high-dimensional linear space given in (32), then derive the corresponding kernel separability model expressed in (33) by right of kernel trick. 6. Set up the pairwise KDSFA model according to (34), then compute the fault direction α S by solving a generalized eigenvalue decomposition given in (35). 7. Calculate the historical fault direction α H by adopting the pairwise KDSFA to the datasets H and X ∼ . Then figure out the similarity factor S KDSFA defined in (36) to quantify the similarity of the datasets S and H . 8. If the value of S KDSFA is close to 1, the fault snapshot dataset S and historical fault dataset H are the same fault patterns; if the value of S KDSFA tends to be 0, the datasets S and H are the different fault patterns. Output: The identified fault pattern of the fault snapshot dataset S . Table 3 The monitored variables and their physical meanings of the AHU system. Air handling unit (AHU) is a typical special batch control process, exhibiting strong nonlinear property and two-directional dynamic characteristics which are the time-wise and batch-wise dynamic characteristics. Specifically, the time-wise dynamic characteristic corresponds to the evolution of different operating modes caused by the underlying driving forces which vary slowly in each running day (a batch run), while the batch-wise dynamic characteristic relates to the dynamic variations and deviations among different running days (batch runs). In order to further improve the AHU FDD performance through capturing the underlying driving forces of the AHU system and tackling the batch-wise dynamic property between different batch runs, in this paper, an enhanced kernel slow feature analysis (SFA) based FDD scheme is developed to detect and identify the faults of the nonlinear AHU system. Firstly, a three-way data based kernel SFA (TBKSFA) approach is proposed to detect the faults. In the proposed TBKSFA approach, the kernel trick is adopted in the SFA to sufficiently deal with the nonlinearity and the time-wise dynamic characteristic, and the multiway data analysis is employed to cope with the batch-wise dynamics among different batch runs by converting the three-way training dataset into a variable-wise unfolding two-way matrix. In addition, to handle the tough problem of nonlinearly identifying the fault pattern, a novel kernel discriminant SFA (KDSFA) model is further built by combining the kernel SFA with the discriminant analysis method. In the fault pattern diagnosis process, the proposed KDSFA is pairwisely implemented on the normal and fault datasets to calculate the fault direction, and the fault is then identified by computing the similar degrees of its own fault direction and the historical fault directions. At last, experiments and comparisons on the FDD performance of the developed approach are made using the experimental data provided by ASHRAE Research Project RP-1312. To be specific, the proposed TBKSFA based fault detection method is compared with the popular kernel principal component analysis (KPCA) method, the closely related kernel SFA method and the emerging manifold learning based kernel locality preserving projections (KLPP) method. While the developed KDSFA based fault pattern diagnosis scheme is compared with the conventional jointed angle analysis technique, the strongly linked DSFA based method and the rising artificial neural networks based long short-term memory(LSTM) classifier. Experimental results demonstrate that significant improvements can be achieved by the proposed approach compared with some other popular methods. Keywords Air handling unit Fault detection and diagnosis Kernel slow feature analysis Multiway data analysis Discriminant analysis Abbreviations AHU air handing unit ASHRAE American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-conditioning Engineers DC damper controller DSFA discriminant slow feature analysis FC flow rate controller SVM support vector machine FDD fault detection and diagnosis HVAC heating, ventilating and air conditioning H F historical fault dataset JAA joint angle analysis J Separa objective function of the inter-class separability KDE kernel density estimation KDSFA kernel discriminant slow feature analysis K-NN K-nearest neighborhood KPCA kernel principle component analysis KSFA kernel slow feature analysis PC pressure controller PCA principle component analysis RCD recognition contrast degree REI recognition error index RP research project SFA slow feature analysis SPE squared prediction error S DSFA similarity factor of DSFA method S F fault snapshot dataset S KDSFA similarity factor of KDSFA method S P - JAA similarity factor of JAA method in principal component space T 2 Hotelling’s T 2 statistic TBKSFA three-way data based kernel slow feature analysis TC temperature controller T ma mixed air temperature T sa supply air temperature VAV variable air volume 1 Introduction The abnormal operation and faults occurred in the Heating, ventilating and air conditioning (HVAC) system, such as the equipments’ degradation and the improper maintenance, would result in a significant waste of energy used in buildings. Therefore, the fault detection and diagnosis (FDD) approaches are urgently needed to save energy and to avert the breakdown of the HVAC components. As a vital component of the HVAC system, the air handling unit (AHU) is used to adjust the temperature and humidity of the air which will be provided to different rooms and zones. The faults of the AHU can not only shorten the lives of equipments, but also lead to the building energy waste and the indoor discomfort [1]. Thus, it is an important task to explore effective approaches to detect and remove the faults in the AHU system. 1.1 The related works In recent years, a large number of data-driven approaches have been developed for the AHU system FDD through making full use of the rich measured and recorded process operating data [2,3]. The data-driven FDD approaches include two main categories: the multivariate statistical analysis approaches and the advanced artificial intelligence approaches [1,4]. The principle component analysis (PCA) technique, as a typical multivariate statistical analysis approach, was widely adopted to implement process FDD for the AHU systems. Du et al. [5] suggested an incorporation of PCA and joint angle analysis (JAA) to monitor and recognize faults in the AHU system. To detect and isolate multiple faults in the AHU system, Shahnazari et al. [6] presented an improved PCA based on the linear causal model. Li et al. [7] discussed a wavelet-PCA based AHU system fault detection strategy by integrating the wavelet transform into the basic PCA. To denoise the noise information of the raw measured data, Li et al. [8] combined the ensemble empirical mode decomposition with the PCA algorithm. However, these PCA based FDD methods for the AHU system are indeed the linear analysis techniques which will encounter some limitations when detecting the faults of the AHU system that is intrinsically a nonlinear system with strong parameter coupling. To effectively deal with the nonlinearity of the AHU system, advanced artificial intelligence methods, which have powerful abilities to nonlinearly map the original data samples into new feature spaces, have drawn more and more attentions in recent years [9,10]. For example, to take advantage of the faults information, Zhao et al. [11,12] presented one Bayesian network based fault diagnosis approach for the AHU system. He et al. [13] discussed a novel Baysian network classifier to promote the fault detection efficacy. Yan et al. [14] suggested a semi-supervised support vector machine (SVM) approach to cope with the imbalanced training dataset. An unsupervised SVM was integrated with the Gaussian process regression technique to recognize the AHU faults in [15]. These advanced artificial intelligence based FDD approaches utilize the whole raw process data as inputs in the model training stage instead of selecting the key process variables, which would lead to the FDD performance deterioration because of the noisy information and the redundant variables in the raw process data. To tackle such problems, some improved methods have been given. For example, to choose the essential features from the measured redundant information of the AHU system, an information greedy feature filter based FDD method was presented in [16], an improved rapid centroid estimation method was developed in [17], and a feature selection based fault diagnosis method utilizing an improved distance rejection technique was provided in [18]. However, the monitoring models of the aforementioned FDD methods are built based on the steady state operations of the AHU system where the training data is assumed to be time-invariant [1]. Such FDD approaches have the common shortcomings to capture the time-varying dynamic behaviors of the AHU system. In view of the time-varying dynamic behaviors during the AHU operation, some dynamic FDD techniques have been proposed for the AHU system. To deal with the dynamic characteristics among sensors and in sensors’ readings, Li et al. [19] discussed a data-temporal attention network based FDD method to diagnose faults. Karami et al. [20] developed a novel adaptive Gaussian mixture model based FDD method to mine the time-varying nature. Bonvini et al. [21] presented a nonlinear state estimation approach to track the dynamic evolution of the operating modes in the HVAC components. In [22], Wang et al. suggested a revised adaptive PCA model to track the normal dynamic variations in the AHU systems. Although better FDD performance can be achieved, in the existing dynamic FDD techniques, the extracted latent variables are still independent instead of being relevant to previous values [23,24]. Subsequently, these dynamic FDD approaches are not very good at handling the time-varying dynamic behaviors of the AHU system because of their insufficient capacity to capture the slowly-varying underlying driving forces, i.e., the slowly-varying underlying parameters caused by the sequencing control logic [6]. 1.2 The motivations of our work In the actual operation, owning to the variations of outdoor weather and indoor temperature, humidity and load conditions during a day, the AHU system usually works at extensive operating conditions and has multiple operating modes such as the mechanical heating mode, the free cooling mode and the mechanical cooling mode and so forth to remain comfortable indoor environments [16]. The switches of these multiple operating modes are determined by the sequencing control logic [6], referred to as the slowly-varying underlying driving forces. In addition, the outdoor climate and indoor conditions such as the indoor occupants, loads and the setting values of the temperature and humidity controllers usually do not change dramatically during several days or even several weeks, which leads to the AHU system running repeatedly with small variations and deviations from day to day [1,25]. Considering such kind of operating characteristics of the AHU system, its running process can be regarded as a special batch control process. Being similar to the analysis of the batch control process, the running of the AHU system during one day is considered as one batch run and the operating data collected from this day is deemed as one batch data. The AHU operating data collected from different running days under similar outdoor climate and indoor conditions are identified as different batch datasets. Based on the above analysis, the AHU system generally has the two-directional dynamic time-varying properties: the time-wise dynamic property and the batch-wise dynamic property. The time-wise dynamic property relates to the intrinsical time-varying dynamic behaviors such as the changes of the operating modes, the alterations of the feedback control and so on in each batch run, while the batch-wise dynamic property reflects the dynamic variations between multiple batch runs which result from the small shifts of outdoor climate and indoor conditions among different running days. Hence, the developed FDD methods should cope with both the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system. However, as discussed in Section 1.1, the existing AHU dynamic FDD methods are inadequate in tackling the time-wise dynamics because they cannot mine the slowly-varying underlying driving forces of the AHU system. Furthermore, the batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system have not been considered till now. In the field of process control, it has been confirmed that the slowly-varying underlying driving forces can characterize the time-wise dynamic behaviors within a batch run. Recently, slow feature analysis (SFA) has been applied to manage the time-wise dynamics in the batch control process due to its superiority of extracting slowly-varying slow features (SFs) from the dynamic data [26]. To handle the time-wise dynamics, Zhang et al. [27] presented one global preserving based SFA approach for the fault detection of the industrial process. In [28], a discriminant analysis based SFA method was proposed to detect and diagnose the batch control process fault by utilizing the class label information. In [29], an improved SFA was developed to distinguish the fault in the time-wise dynamics or the steady-state operation. In [30], a revised statistics SFA based monitoring scheme was given to deal with the multiple phase information of the batch control process. Experimental results in [27–30] verified that the SFA based FDD methods are more efficient to exploit the intrinsical time-wise dynamic property of the batch control process because such methods offer a superior way to mine the slowly-varying underlying driving forces. On the other aspect, the multiway data analysis technique can efficiently cope with the batch-wise dynamic deviations and variations between multiple batch runs [31,32]. The multiway data analysis technique converts the three-way training dataset constructed using multiple normal batch datasets into a variable-wise unfolding two-way matrix. This two-way matrix can be directly carried out by the SFA based method to dispose of the batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system. As a result, with the help of the multiway data analysis technique, the SFA based FDD method can tackle both the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system. After a fault is detected, we need the fault diagnosis to eliminate the fault effects and bring the AHU system back to normal status. However, the primary target of the TBKSFA is only to detect the fault instead of going on investigating how to diagnose the fault. The contribution plot [33], the reconstruction based contribution plot [34] and the joint angle analysis (JAA) technique [5,6,35] are the popular methods for fault diagnosis. Nevertheless, the contribution plot and the reconstruction based contribution plot are unfeasible to discern the fault variable, because they need to calculate the variables’ contribution degrees. But these contribution degrees cannot be found in the TBKSFA approach. The JAA utilizes the linear PCA to extract the principal component vectors from the AHU data, so it cannot tackle the nonlinear property of the AHU system. Besides, the JAA cannot exploit the class label information of the AHU system because it is indeed an unsupervised technology. To deal with such problems, a new fault pattern nonlinear identification algorithm based on kernel discriminant SFA (KDSFA) is further developed by computing the similar degrees between fault directions of snapshot and historical fault datasets. 1.3 The main contributions To the best of the authors’ knowledge, in the research domain of the AHU FDD, there exists few studies focused on the SFA based FDD approaches for the AHU system. In order to tackle both the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics of the nonlinear AHU system and to improve the FDD performance, in this paper, we regard the AHU system as a type of nonlinear batch control process, and develop the enhanced kernel SFA based approaches for the FDD of the AHU system. Besides, to reveal the superior effectiveness of the proposed FDD methods, detailed experiments and comparisons are performed on the ASHRAE AHU dataset. Specifically, the developed TBKSFA based fault detection method is compared with the KPCA, KSFA and kernel locality preserving projections (KLPP) [36,37] based monitoring methods. This is because the KPCA is a typical and well-known multivariate statistical analysis method; the KSFA is the basic foundation of the developed TBKSFA; the KLPP is a promising manifold learning based method. Moreover, considering the JAA technique is a conditional and popular fault diagnosis method; the suggested KDSFA is a further improvement of the DSFA; the long short-term memory (LSTM) [38–40] classifier is an emerging and well-working artificial neural networks based fault diagnosis method, the suggested KDSFA based fault pattern identification scheme is contrasted with the JAA, DSFA and LSTM based methods. The main novelties and contributions in our work are listed as follows: • To tackle the batch-wise dynamics among multiple batch runs, the multiway data analysis technique is adopted to analyze the three-way training dataset. In this method, the three-way training dataset, which is constructed by the multiple operating datasets from different running days, is firstly transformed to be a normalized batch-wise unfolding two-way matrix, and be rearranged into a new variable-wise unfolding two-way matrix further. The final matrix is utilized as the input of the developed detection model. • The three-way data based kernel SFA (TBKSFA) method is proposed to handle the nonlinearity and mine the time-wise dynamic property of the AHU system. In the TBKSFA method, the kernel trick is integrated into the linear SFA model to capture the nonlinear feature by avoiding the complicated nonlinear optimization procedure. Owning to the SFA’s superiority of extracting the slowly-varying underlying driving forces, the proposed TBKSFA method can adequately address the time-wise dynamic property in a batch run. • To realize the nonlinear identification of fault patterns in the AHU system, a kernel discriminant SFA (KDSFA) based fault diagnosis scheme is presented. The aim of employing this discriminant analysis technique is to make full use of the class label information of the nonlinear AHU data. Firstly, the KDSFA is pairwisely performed on the normal operating dataset and each historical fault dataset to find the fault direction, and separate them optimally. And then, the fault pattern is determined via measuring the similar degrees of the fault directions. • Detailed experiments on the experimental data provided by the ASHRAE Research Project RP-1312 are made, and comparisons with some related methods, such as the KPCA, KSFA and KLPP based fault detection methods as well as the JAA, DSFA and LSTM based fault diagnosis methods, are given. Experimental and comparison results demonstrate that the proposed method has excellent FDD performance and can achieve significant improvements compared with the comparative methods. The remaining part of this paper is as follows. In Section 2, the AHU system and the SFA method are introduced briefly. In order to monitor the AHU system operating status, the TBKSFA based fault detection approach is first proposed in Section 3, which is the first stage of the suggested enhanced KSFA based FDD approach. After a fault is detected by the TBKSFA method, in Section 4, the KDSFA based fault diagnosis approach is then presented to identify the fault pattern of collected fault dataset, which is the second stage of the suggested enhanced KSFA based FDD approach. Finally, Section 5 summarizes the whole fault detection and diagnosis strategy of the proposed enhanced KSFA approach for the AHU system, including the fault detection strategy of the TBKSFA based method and the fault pattern identification strategy of the KDSFA based method. Experiments and comparisons are shown in Section 6. At last, the conclusion is made in Section 7. 2 Preliminaries 2.1 The AHU system The AHU system is an important component of the HVAC system in commercial and residential buildings [41,42]. The most widely used AHU system is the variable air volume (VAV) AHU system as illustrated in Fig. 1 . In this kind of AHU system, the VAV subsystem is commonly installed, where a variable frequency driver is configurated with the supply fan to modulate the air flow in accordance with the variations of indoor load conditions. And, the cooling coil and heating coil are utilized to cool, heat and dehumidify the supply air which is fed into different terminal units through the ductwork in multiple zones. The air in different zones is brought back to the AHU system through the return duct. The circulation of air in the supply ductwork and return ductwork is respectively facilitated by the supply and return fans with a constant air pressure difference. In order to minimize the energy consumption, different control schemes are adopted in the AHU system to maintain the proper supply air temperature, indoor air pressure and sufficient outdoor air ventilation. To be specific, four PID controllers, i.e., the damper controller (DC-1), the return air flow rate controller (FC-1), the supply air static pressure controller (PC-1) and the supply air temperature controller (TC-1), are involved in this AHU system to control the outdoor air flow rate, the return fan speed, the supply air static pressure and the supply air temperature. To make the supply air temperature ( T sa ) keep constant when furnished to the AHU terminals for conditioning the air, the AHU system measures the temperature T sa online and compares the value of T sa with the setting value of the temperature controller TC-1. For the purpose of manipulating the outside and return air dampers automatically to acquire suitable air mixing temperature ( T ma ) before the mixed air enters coils, the output signal of the controller TC-1 is served as one input signal of the controller DC-1. Besides, the setpoints of the return air flow difference, the supply air temperature and the supply air static pressure control loops are reset timely by some reasonable control schemes according to the actual operating conditions. In its running, improper operations, defective system designs and so forth may lead to different kinds of faults in the sensors and controllers. Depending on the causes and locations of the faults, there are several types of typical faults in the AHU system, which are the valves leakage, the dampers stuck and the bias in the sensor measurements, etc. Realizing the effective FDD of such faults is one necessary task to assure the normal operation of the AHU system. But, as discussed in the Introduction, it is not easy to perform the FDD, because the operating modes in the AHU system vary dynamically along with the outdoor weather as well as indoor temperature, humidity and load conditions during a day. This will result in the time-wise dynamics within a batch run. During several days or even several weeks, the AHU system runs repeatedly with small variations and deviations from day to day, which reveals the batch-wise dynamics. Taking into account of the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics, it requires the FDD method to track the operating modes’ time-varying dynamic evolution as well as to handle the dynamic variations among different running days in the AHU system [21]. 2.2 The SFA method The main goal of SFA is to derive the output variables that have slow changes from the input data. Given the input vector x ( t ) = [ x 1 ( t ) , … , x m ( t ) ] T , SFA seeks the transformation functions g ( x ) = [ g 1 ( x ) , … , g J ( x ) ] T to ensure that the output vector y ( t ) = [ y 1 ( t ) , … , y J ( t ) ] T has the slowest variations, where y j ( t ) = g j ( x ( t ) ) . The optimization problem of the SFA is defined as (1) min ( y ̇ j ( t ) ) 2 (2) s . t . y j ( t ) = 0 (3) y j 2 ( t ) = 1 (4) ∀ i ≠ j : y i ( t ) y j ( t ) = 0 where y j ( t ) is the j-th slow feature, y ̇ j ( t ) indicates the first order derivative of y j ( t ) , · is the averaging computation operator, the Eq. (1) ensures that the output variables possess the slowest variations, (2) is performed to guarantee the means of the output variables to be zero, (3) is employed to eliminate the constant solution, (4) ensures that the output variables are mutually orthogonal. The averaging computation operator · can be computed as (5) f ( t ) = 1 t 1 - t 0 ∫ t 0 t 1 f ( t ) d t The j-th slow feature has faster variation than the ( j - 1 ) -th slow feature, i.e. the first latent variable y 1 ( t ) has the slowest variation and the second variations variable y 2 ( t ) has the second slowest variation, and so on. If g j ( · ) is a linear mapping, y j ( t ) can be rewritten as y j ( t ) = w j T x ( t ) , where w j represents the loading vector. Then, the optimization problem of the SFA can be formulated as (6) min y ̇ j 2 ( t ) t = min w j w j T x ̇ ( t ) x ̇ T ( t ) w j = min w j w j T Aw j s . t . y j 2 ( t ) t = w j T x ( t ) x T ( t ) w j = w j T Bw j = 1 where A represents the covariance of x ̇ ( t ) and B indicates the covariance of x ( t ) . If the input samples are measured and recorded in a discrete time interval, x ̇ ( t ) can be computed as follows [23,24,43] (7) x ̇ ( t ) = dx ( t ) dt ≈ x ( t ) - x ( t - 1 ) , t = 2 , 3 , … , T The optimization problem in (6) can be converted into a generalized eigenvalue decomposition form as (8) Aw j = λ j Bw j The slowest feature corresponds to the smallest value of λ , while the second slowest feature corresponds to the second smallest value of λ , and so on. For the purpose of extracting slow features from the nonlinear process data, many nonlinear revisions of SFA were studied [26,44]. To avert the problem of computing nonlinear mapping explicitly, kernel SFA based approaches [45–47] have been discussed to perform process monitoring. These methods have the capability to build the nonlinear fault detection models by the kernel trick. 3 The Proposed TBKSFA Model for the Fault Detection of the AHU System According to the previous investigation on the operating characteristics of the AHU system, it can be regarded as a special kind of batch control process. Its operating data collected from one running day under different operating modes is considered as one batch run dataset. This batch run dataset has the time-wise dynamic property. The data collected from different running days under similar outdoor climate and indoor conditions are identified as different batch run datasets. Such datasets can reflect the batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system. However, as aforementioned, the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics are not well addressed by the conventional FDD approaches. In this section, to resolve these problems during monitoring the AHU system, we will propose the three-way data based kernel SFA (TBKSFA) to detect the AHU faults more effectively, which is indeed the first part of the suggested EKSFA based FDD approach. The developed TBKSFA based fault detection method includes two core modules as illustrated in Fig. 2 . The first module adopts the multiway data analysis technique to tackle the batch-wise dynamic characteristic among multiple batch runs, while the second one employs the kernel SFA method to handle the nonlinearity and mine the time-wise dynamic property of the AHU system. Below, we will present the details of these two modules of the TBKSFA based fault detection method. 3.1 Multiway data analysis of the AHU system To begin, we assume that the normal datasets of the AHU system have been collected for a long-term operating period (several days or weeks), i.e., multiple batch run datasets have been obtained. The obtained datasets are denoted as the two-way matrices X i ( J × K ) , where i = 1 , 2 , … , I , I denotes the number of batch runs corresponding to different running days, J and K indicate the numbers of process variables and data samples in each batch run. Then, a three-way model training dataset X ( I × J × K ) can be constructed by these I normal batch run datasets. Further, we unfold the three-way training dataset into a new two-way data matrix as the input of the detection model. This will be achieved by the multiway data analysis technique [31,32], which is illustrated in Fig. 3 . The detailed steps of the whole multiway data analysis procedure are as follows. The first step is to split the training dataset X ( I × J × K ) into K vertical time slice matrices X k ( I × J ) , k = 1 , 2 , … , K along the sampling time direction. Then, a batch-wise unfolding procedure is performed to transform the matrix X ( I × J × K ) into a two-way matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) by arranging the K time slice matrices in the batch-wise direction. The batch-wise unfolding allows us to analyze and remove the dynamic variabilities among different batch runs in the three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) in terms of the variations of both the variables and time. In the second step, the two-way matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) is normalized to be the data matrix X ( I × KJ ) which have the zero mean and the unit standard deviation. More specifically, assuming that X ∼ ( I × KJ ) = [ x ∼ 1 T , x ∼ 2 T , … , x ∼ I T ] , where x ∼ i ∈ R KJ × 1 denotes the i-th vector of the training matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) , the i-th vector x ∼ i is firstly normalized as (9) x i = x ∼ i - mean ( X ∼ ( I × KJ ) ) std ( X ∼ ( I × KJ ) ) , i = 1 , 2 , … , I where mean ( · ) and std ( · ) respectively indicate the mean and standard deviation operators implemented on the whole training matrix X ∼ ( I × KJ ) . And then, the normalized data matrix X ( I × KJ ) can be established by such normalized vectors as X ( I × KJ ) = [ x 1 T , x 2 T , … , x I T ] . In the final step, a variable-wise unfolding procedure is adopted to rearrange the matrix X ( I × KJ ) into a new two-way training matrix X ( IK × J ) . This procedure is implemented by stacking the K time slice matrices X k ( I × J ) along the variable-wise direction. 3.2 The kernel SFA model for detecting the faults of the AHU system The SFA has the capacity to capture the slowly-varying underlying driving forces, hence, in this subsection, we will build the kernel SFA model to adequately mine the time-wise dynamics from the nonlinear AHU system. Besides, the kernel trick will be adopted in the kernel SFA method to develop the nonlinear detection model without explicitly calculating the nonlinear mapping function. In this kernel SFA method, the nonlinear running data is firstly mapped into a high-dimensional feature space by the kernel functions, and then, the SFA is carried out in the feature space to extract the slow features. The presented kernel SFA method includes three main steps: the pseudo time series matrix reconstruction, the kernel model derivation, the slow features extraction. In the following, we will describe these three steps in detail. 3.2.1 The pseudo time series matrix reconstruction When we construct the matrix X ( IK × J ) using the K time slice matrices X k ( I × J ) , k = 1 , 2 , … , K , the temporal series information is destroyed. To address this issue, we need to establish the pseudo time series firstly for the following kernel SFA modeling. Suppose that the i-th vector in matrix X k ( I × J ) is denoted as x k ( i ) ∈ R J for 1 ⩽ i ⩽ I . Then, we select its l nearest neighboring vectors, expressed as x k j ( i ) , j = 1 , 2 , … , l , by the K-nearest neighborhood (K-NN) principle from the matrix X k ( I × J ) . Further, a pseudo time series with respect to vector x k ( i ) can be established as (10) t k ( i ) = [ x k ( i ) , x k 1 ( i ) , x k ( i ) , x k 2 ( i ) , … , x k ( i ) , x k l ( i ) ] T ∈ R 2 l × J On this basis, we build a pseudo time series matrix for time slice matrix X k ( I × J ) as T k ( 2 Il × J ) = [ t k ( 1 ) , t k ( 2 ) , … , t k ( I ) ] T . Similarly, a pseudo time series matrix T ( 2 IKl × J ) of the training matrix X ( IK × J ) can be determined as (11) T ( 2 IKl × J ) = [ T 1 T , T 1 T , … , T K T ] T Denote the ( 2 i - 1 ) -th and 2 i -th samples in the matrix T ( 2 IKl × J ) as τ ( 2 i - 1 ) ∈ R J and τ ( 2 i ) ∈ R J for 1 ⩽ i ⩽ IKl . The temporal variations are deemed to exist between samples τ ( 2 i - 1 ) and τ ( 2 i ) . The matrices T ( 2 IKl × J ) and X ( IK × J ) can be then utilized in the TBKSFA method. 3.2.2 The kernel model derivation As aforementioned, the nonlinear mapping function ϕ ( · ) transforms the matrices X and T from the original nonlinear space into new matrices ϕ ( X ) and ϕ ( T ) , abbreviated as X ϕ and T ϕ , in the high-dimensional linear space. To obtain the TBKSFA model, the following optimization problem needs to be solved. (12) J TBKSFA = min w j 1 IKl - 1 w j T ∑ i = 1 IKl ( τ ϕ ( 2 i ) - τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) ( τ ϕ ( 2 i ) - τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) T w j s . t . 1 IK - 1 w j T ∑ i = 1 IK x ϕ ( i ) x ϕ T ( i ) w j = 1 where τ ϕ ( 2 i ) = ϕ ( τ ( 2 i ) ) , τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) = ϕ ( τ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) , x ϕ ( i ) = ϕ ( x ( i ) ) , and the vector x i indicates the i-th sample in the matrix X ( IK × J ) . This optimization problem is very challenging because the nonlinear function ϕ ( · ) is unknown. Considering that the loading vector w j can be rewritten as a linear combination of IK vectors ϕ ( x ( i ) ) as follows [48,49] (13) w j = ∑ i = 1 IK ϕ ( x ( i ) ) α ij = X ϕ T α j where α ij indicates the i-th element of coefficient vector α j . Then, substituting this equation into (12) leads to the following optimization problem (14) J TBKSFA = min α j 1 IKl - 1 α j T X ϕ ∑ i = 1 IKl ( τ ϕ ( 2 i ) - τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) ( τ ϕ ( 2 i ) - τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) T X ϕ T α j = min α j 1 IKl - 1 α j T ∑ i = 1 IKl ( X ϕ τ ϕ ( 2 i ) - X ϕ τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) ( τ ϕ T ( 2 i ) X ϕ T - τ ϕ T ( 2 i - 1 ) X ϕ T ) α j (15) s . t . 1 IK - 1 α j T X ϕ X ϕ T X ϕ X ϕ T α j = 1 With the aid of kernel trick, the inner product of the nonlinear mapped vectors can be calculated by the kernel function ϕ T ( x ) ϕ ( y ) = ker ( x , y ) [50]. In this way, we can calculate the kernel vectors k 2 i = X ϕ τ ϕ ( 2 i ) and k 2 i - 1 = X ϕ τ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) , where the j-th elements of k 2 i and k 2 i - 1 are defined as k 2 i , j = ker ( x ( j ) , τ ( 2 i ) ) and k 2 i - 1 , j = ker ( x ( j ) , τ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) for j = 1 , 2 , … , IK . The kernel matrix K can also be computed as K = X ϕ X ϕ T , where its ( i , j ) -th element is defined by K ( i , j ) = ker ( x ( i ) , x ( j ) ) in which i , j = 1 , 2 , … , IK . However, the kernel function employed by TBKSFA is not arbitrary. According to Mercer’s theorem of functional analysis [50], a specific choice of kernel function implicitly determines the nonlinear mapping and the high-dimensional feature space. In TBKSFA, the selection of a kernel function is an important issue since the degree of capturing nonlinear characteristics of the AHU system is dependent upon it. Nevertheless, for a given monitoring process, the general question of how to choose an ideal kernel function is still an open problem [48]. As well-known, there exits three classical kernel functions: polynomial kernel: ker ( x , y ) = x , y d , Gaussian kernel ker ( x , y ) = exp ( - ‖ x - y ‖ 2 / δ ) and sigmoid kernel ker ( x , y ) = tan h ( β 0 x , y + β 1 ) , where d , δ , β 0 and β 1 are specified by the user. The polynomial kernel and the Gaussian kernel always satisfy Mercer’s theorem, whereas the sigmoid kernel satisfies it only for some certain values of β 0 and β 1 [50]. Among them, the Gaussian kernel is the most widely used kernel function [48]. In our study, the Gaussian kernel will be chosen for the nonlinear mapping to follow the references [48,51], because it is more suitable to mine the nonlinearity of the AHU system than other representative kernel functions. By using the kernel vectors k 2 i and k 2 i - 1 as well as the kernel matrix K , and denote L k = 1 IKl - 1 ∑ i = 1 IKl ( k 2 i - k 2 i - 1 ) ( k 2 i - k 2 i - 1 ) T , then the optimization problem in (14) and (15) can be rewritten as (16) J TBKSFA = min α j 1 IKl - 1 α j T ∑ i = 1 IKl ( k 2 i - k 2 i - 1 ) ( k 2 i - k 2 i - 1 ) T α j = min α j α j T L k α j s . t . 1 IK - 1 α j T KK T α j = 1 in which L k is the kernel pseudo temporal variation matrix. 3.2.3 Slow features extraction The previous optimization problem can be figured out by computing the following generalized eigenvalue decomposition. (17) L K α j = 1 IK - 1 λ j KK T α j The solution of (17) brings the generalized eigenvectors A IK = [ α 1 , α 2 , … , α IK ] , which are corresponding to the generalized eigenvalues λ 1 < λ 2 < … < λ IK . These generalized eigenvectors corresponds to the extracted slow features. Specifically, the smaller the generalized eigenvalue is, the slower varying trend the slow feature will have. The variations of the underlying driving forces in the AHU system can be caught by the slowly-varying slow features while the short-term fluctuations can be characterized by the rapidly-varying slow features. Too many slow features would lead to unnecessary emphasis on the short-term fluctuations and noises, and will deteriorate the fault detection performance. To reduce the dimension of data, the first p vital generalized eigenvectors A p = [ α 1 , α 2 , … , α p ] are selected to extract the slowest varying slow features that contain the crucial process information. In this work, we determine the parameter p by calculating the cumulative slowness contribution rate of slow features. Considering that λ represents slowness level of the corresponding slow feature, the cumulative slowness contribution rate of the j-th slow feature is defined as (18) R p = ∑ j = 1 p μ j / ∑ j = 1 IK μ j where μ j = 1 / λ j for j = 1 , 2 , … , IK . To build the TBKSFA model, p is selected according to the 95% contribution rate. On the basis of the derived slow features, in order to monitor a test sample x te , the statistics T 2 and SPE are constructed as (19) T 2 = k te T A p A p T k te (20) SPE = k te T A IK A IK T k te - k te T A p A p T k te where the statistic T 2 is established to capture the primary slowly-varying trends of the AHU system in the principal component space, and k te = ϕ ( X ) ϕ ( x te ) represents the kernel vector of the test sample x te . The statistic SPE is built to quantify the short-term fluctuations of the AHU system in the residual space. To judge the status of the test sample x te , the respective threshold values of the monitoring statistics T 2 and SPE are required. In order to determine the monitoring threshold values, many process monitoring methods requires the process variables follow some specified distribution. Specifically, assuming the process variables follows a multivariate normal distribution, the PCA based methods respectively compute the threshold values of the monitoring statistics T 2 and SPE based on the F distribution and weighted χ 2 distribution [52]. However, it is difficult to guarantee the AHU process variables conform to a specific distribution assumption, such as multivariate Gaussian distribution, because the prior knowledge is not available about the process variables’ distribution. Hence, the threshold values of the monitoring statistics T 2 and SPE in the proposed TBKSFA method cannot be determined directly from a particular approximate distribution. The kernel density estimation (KDE) is a nonparametric empirical density estimation technique, which does not need any assumption of the process variables’ distribution. Recently, the data-driven based KDE method has been broadly adopted to determine the monitoring threshold values [48,52,53]. Therefore, we employ the KDE technique to estimate the threshold values of the monitoring statistics T 2 and SPE in the TBKSFA based method. Based on these two threshold values, the TBKSFA method can realize the fault detection objective. 3.3 The pseudo code of the TBKSFA algorithm Here, the pseudo code of the TBKSFA based approach for the fault detection of the AHU system is given in Table 1 . 4 The KDSFA similarity factor based nonlinear diagnosis of the fault pattern When a fault is detected in the AHU system, fault diagnosis is a critical issue of eliminating the fault effects. However, few research works reported how to cope with the troublesome issue of nonlinearly discerning fault pattern. The contribution plot [33] and reconstruction based contribution plot [34] based fault variable recognition methods are seldom studied in kernel based methods because contributions of process variables cannot be computed after the nonlinear mapping. Furthermore, the JAA based approaches [5,6,35] are not suitable to identify the fault pattern of the nonlinear AHU system because they cannot handle the nonlinear characteristics or utilize the class label information of process data. To figure out the problem of nonlinearly identifying fault patterns in the AHU system, in this section, a new kernel discriminant SFA (KDSFA) based fault diagnosis algorithm as shown in Fig. 4 will be developed, which is actually the second part of the suggested enhanced KSFA based FDD approach. Below, we will firstly describe how to construct the pairwise KDSFA method, and then show the computation of the similarity degrees for the final fault diagnosis. 4.1 Construction of the pairwise KDSFA model The AHU system data tends to contain a plenty of faulty samples because different faults would take place in the long-term operating period. By integrating the discriminant analysis technique into the KSFA method, the KDSFA approach will be presented to use the class discriminatory information of the fault data as well as to handle the nonlinear property of the AHU system. To be specific, as displayed in Fig. 4, there are three core modules in the developed KDSFA approach. The first module constructs the intra-class kernel SFA model only utilizing the fault snapshot dataset to preserve the local geometrical structure. The second module establishes the inter-class kernel separability model based on the fault snapshot dataset and normal dataset to optimally separate these two datasets. The final one builds the pairwise KDSFA model to extract the faut direction of the snapshot dataset, through minimizing the objective function of the intra-class kernel SFA model while maximizing the objective function of the inter-class kernel separability model. Below, we will formulate the details of these three core modules for the proposed KDSFA method. 4.1.1 The intra-class kernel SFA model for the fault snapshot dataset The intra-class kernel SFA model involves three main steps: construction of the fault snapshot dataset, calculation of the intra-class temporal variation, derivation of the kernel SFA model. Below, we will present these three steps in details. In the first step, suppose that n s fault samples are detected and stored, these fault samples is then used to establish the fault snapshot dataset S = [ x s ( 1 ) , x s ( 2 ) , … , x s ( n s ) ] T ∈ R n s × J . Further, the fault snapshot dataset S is normalized to have the zero mean and the standard deviation on the ground of the training dataset. In the second step, considering that the fault sample x s ( k ) is always measured using the discrete manner in practice, the temporal structure information would exist in the fault snapshot dataset S . Hence, the intra-class temporal variance in the dataset S is empirically approximated as [23,24,54] (21) x ̇ s ( k ) ≈ x s ( k ) - x s ( k - 1 ) where the vector x ̇ s ( k ) denotes the first-order temporal derivative. In the third step, let matrix S ϕ = [ x s , ϕ ( 1 ) , x s , ϕ ( 2 ) , … , x s , ϕ ( n s ) ] T represent the transformation of the dataset S in the high-dimensional feature space, where x s , ϕ ( k ) = ϕ ( x s ( k ) ) . The kernel SFA model is built based on the matrix S ϕ and its objective function can be formulated as (22) J KSFA = min w j 1 n s - 2 ∑ k = 2 n s w j T x ̇ s , ϕ ( k ) x ̇ s , ϕ T ( k ) w j = min w j 1 n s - 2 ∑ k = 2 n s w j T ( x s , ϕ ( k ) - x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) ) ( x s , ϕ ( k ) - x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) ) T w j where x ̇ s , ϕ ( k ) = ϕ ( x ̇ s , ϕ ( k ) ) = x s , ϕ ( k ) - x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) and w j represents the j-th loading vector. According to the theory of the kernel trick, the loading vector w j lies in the space spanned by the samples ϕ ( x ‾ 1 ) , ϕ ( x ‾ 2 ) , … , ϕ ( x ‾ K ) of the matrix X ‾ ϕ = ϕ ( X ‾ ) , which indicates the average training dataset in the high-dimensional feature space. So, the loading vector w j can be expressed as (23) w j = ∑ k = 1 K α j , k ϕ ( x ‾ k ) = ϕ ( X ‾ ) T α j = X ‾ ϕ T α j where α j , k , k = 1 , 2 , … , K represent the coefficients of the vector α j = [ α j , 1 , α j , 2 , … , α j , K ] T . In order to address the batch-wise dynamic property and decrease the computation complexity, the average training dataset X ‾ is calculated as the average matrix of the three-way training dataset of the AHU system, and can be expressed as (24) X ‾ ( K × J ) = [ x ‾ 1 , x ‾ 2 , … , x ‾ K ] T in which x k ‾ denotes the mean vector of the k-th time slice matrix X k ( I × J ) for k = 1 , 2 , … , K , and can be computed as (25) x ‾ k = 1 I ∑ i = 1 I x k ( i ) , k = 1 , 2 , … , K Substituting (23) into (22) can obtain the following optimization problem. (26) J KSFA = min α j 1 n s - 2 ∑ k = 2 n s α j T X ‾ ϕ ( x s , ϕ ( k ) - x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) ) ( x s , ϕ ( k ) - x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) ) T X ‾ ϕ T α j = min α j 1 n s - 2 ∑ k = 2 n s α j T ( X ‾ ϕ x s , ϕ ( k ) - X ‾ ϕ x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) ) ( x s , ϕ T ( k ) X ‾ ϕ T - x s , ϕ T ( k - 1 ) X ‾ ϕ T ) α j With the help of the Gaussian kernel function ker ( x , y ) = exp ( - ‖ x - y ‖ 2 / σ ) [48,51], the kernel vectors k s ( k ) = X ‾ ϕ x s , ϕ ( k ) and k s ( k - 1 ) = X ‾ ϕ x s , ϕ ( k - 1 ) are computed to avoid the nonlinear transformation function ϕ ( · ) . Then, the optimization problem for the intra-class Kernel SFA can be reformulated as (27) J KSFA = min α j 1 n s - 2 ∑ k = 2 n s α j T ( k s ( k ) - k s ( k - 1 ) ) ( k s ( k ) - k s ( k - 1 ) ) T α j = min α j 1 n s - 2 α j T Δ K s Δ K s T α j = min α j α j T Δ C K α j where the matrix Δ C K = 1 n s - 2 Δ K s Δ K s T ,in which Δ K s denotes the kernel temporal variation matrix of the fault snapshot dataset, and can be constructed as (28) Δ K S = [ Δ k s ( 1 ) , Δ k s ( 2 ) , … , Δ k s ( n s ) ] where Δ k s ( k ) = k s ( k ) , k = 1 k s ( k ) - k s ( k - 1 ) , 1 < k ⩽ n s . 4.1.2 The inter-class kernel separability model using the fault snapshot and normal datasets We need two main steps to construct the inter-class kernel separability model: establishment of the inter-class pseudo time series matrix, derivation of the kernel separability model. Below, the details of these two steps will be exhibited. In the first step, we find that the inter-class separability can be characterized by the distances of samples in the fault snapshot dataset S and their corresponding nearest neighbors in the average training matrix X ‾ . Therefore, the inter-class pseudo time series between the datasets S and X ‾ is established by the K-NN principle in this work. Specifically, denote the i-th sample in the dataset S as x s ( i ) , and express its p nearest neighboring samples in the dataset X ‾ as x s , N f ( i ) , f = 1 , 2 , … , p . An inter-class pseudo time series with respect to the sample x s ( i ) can be built as (29) t b ( i ) = [ x s ( i ) , x s , N 1 ( i ) , x s ( i ) , x s , N 2 ( i ) , … , x s ( i ) , x s , N p ( i ) ] T ∈ R 2 p × J Similarly, the inter-class pseudo time series of the datasets S and X ‾ will be constructed as (30) T b ( 2 n s p × J ) = [ t b T ( 1 ) , t b T ( 2 ) , … , t b T ( n s ) ] T Denote the ( 2 j - 1 ) -th and 2 j -th samples in the matrix T b as μ ( 2 j - 1 ) ∈ R J and μ ( 2 j ) ∈ R J for 1 ⩽ j ⩽ n s p . The temporal variation is thought to exist between samples μ ( 2 j ) and μ ( 2 j - 1 ) , and can be calculated as μ ( 2 j ) - μ ( 2 j - 1 ) . In the second step, the matrix T b is also transformed into a high-dimentional matrix T b ϕ by adopting the nonlinear mapping function ϕ ( · ) , where T b ϕ = ϕ ( T b ) . Subsequently, maximizing the inter-class separability of fault snapshot and normal datasets is equivalent to maximizing the temporal variation of the matrix T b ϕ , which leads to maximize the objective function J Separa below. (31) J Separa = max w j 1 n s p - 1 w j T ∑ i = 1 n s p ( μ ϕ ( 2 i ) - μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) ( μ ϕ ( 2 i ) - μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) T w j where w j is the loading vector and μ ϕ ( 2 i ) = ϕ ( μ ( 2 i ) ) , μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) = ϕ ( μ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) . Recalling that the loading vector w j can be rewritten as: w j = X ‾ ϕ T α j . Thus, this optimization problem can be further rewritten as (32) J Separa = max α j 1 n s p - 1 α j T X ‾ ϕ ∑ i = 1 n s p ( μ ϕ ( 2 i ) - μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) ( μ ϕ ( 2 i ) - μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) T X ‾ ϕ T α j Using the Gaussian kernel function, we can compute the kernel vectors γ 2 i = X ‾ ϕ μ ϕ ( 2 i ) and γ 2 i - 1 = X ‾ ϕ μ ϕ ( 2 i - 1 ) , where the j-th elements of γ 2 i and γ 2 i - 1 are respectively calculated as γ 2 i , j = ker ( x ‾ ( j ) , μ ( 2 i ) ) and γ 2 i - 1 , j = ker ( x ‾ ( j ) , μ ( 2 i - 1 ) ) . With the help of the kernel vectors γ 2 i and γ 2 i - 1 , the previous optimization problem can be formulated as (33) J Separa = max α j 1 n s p - 1 α j T ∑ i = 1 n s p ( γ 2 i - γ 2 i - 1 ) ( γ 2 i - γ 2 i - 1 ) T α j = max α j α j T Q K α j where Q K = 1 n s p - 1 ∑ i = 1 n s p ( γ 2 i - γ 2 i - 1 ) ( γ 2 i - γ 2 i - 1 ) T denotes the kernel inter-class pseudo temporal variation matrix between the datasets S and X ‾ . 4.1.3 The pairwise KDSFA model In order to preserve the intra-class local structure information of the fault snapshot dataset as well as to maximize the inter-class kernel separability of the fault snapshot and normal datasets, we combine the objective function J KSFA with the objective function J Separa together to set up the pairwise KDSFA model. (34) J KDSFA = J KSFA J Separa = min α j α j T Δ C K α j max α j α j T Q K α j = min α j α j T Δ C K α j α j T Q K α j The optimization problem of the pairwise KDSFA can be figured out by calculating a generalized eigenvalue decomposition as follows (35) Δ C K α j = λ j ϕ Q K α j In our work, the fault direction α S of the snapshot dataset S is defined as the generalized eigenvector corresponding to the smallest generalized eigenvalue, which can best reveal the effect of the fault relative to the average training dataset X ‾ . 4.2 Calculating the similarity factor of fault directions Suppose that the fault direction α H of the known historical fault dataset H is computed by adopting the pariwise KDSFA model to the datasets H and X ‾ . The similarity factor S KDSFA is defined to quantify the similarity of the fault snapshot dataset S and the known fault dataset H by the fault directions α S and α H . The defined similarity factor S KDSFA is computed as (36) S KDSFA = α S α H T ‖ α S ‖ · ‖ α H ‖ In fact, the similarity factor S KDSFA is the cosine of angle between the fault directions α S and α H . If the fault snapshot dataset S and the known fault dataset H are the same fault patterns, the value of S KDSFA is close to 1; if these two datasets S and H are the different fault patterns, the value of S KDSFA tends to be 0. The availability of the suggested KDSFA based fault diagnosis approach is evaluated by two performance indices. One is the recognition error index (REI), which considers both the similarity and dissimilarity of the same and different fault patterns respectively, and can be computed as [28,35] (37) REI = ρ + 1 C ∑ i = 1 C | re i | where ρ is set to be 1 for the wrong fault pattern identification and 0 for the right identification, C represents the number of fault patterns, re i = S ( i ) - 1 for i = i real ; re i = S ( i ) - 0 for i ≠ i real , in which S ( i ) denotes the calculated similarity factor and i real indicates the index of the real fault pattern. Obviously, smaller value of REI corresponds to better fault pattern recognition result. The other index is defined to estimate the fault recognition contrast degree, named as the recognition contrast degree (RCD), and can be computed as [28,35] (38) RCD = r · S max - S submax S max where S max and S submax denote the largest and second largest similarity factor values, r is set to be 1 for the right fault pattern recognition and −1 for the wrong recognition. Large RCD value means the convincing, clear and correct fault pattern recognition result. 4.3 The pseudo code of the KDSFA similarity factor algorithm In summary, the pseudo code of the KDSFA similarity factor for the fault diagnosis of the AHU system is illustrated in Table 2 . 5 The proposed enhanced KSFA based FDD strategy for the AHU system As shown in Fig. 5 , the whole FDD strategy of the developed enhanced KSFA approach for the AHU system is summarized in this section. The proposed enhanced KSFA based FDD strategy has two main parts: the TBKSFA based fault detection stage and the KDSFA based fault diagnosis stage. Specifically, the TBKSFA based fault detection stage is first designed to monitor the AHU system operating status, which involves the modeling phase and the monitoring phase. As aforementioned, after a fault of the AHU system is alerted by the TBKSFA based method, the KDSFA based fault diagnosis stage is further proposed to nonlinearly identify the fault pattern, which includes the pairwise KDSFA model construction phase and the similarity factor calculation phase. The enhanced KSFA based FDD scheme proposed in our work is introduced in detail in the following subsections. 5.1 The TBKSFA based fault detection stage 5.1.1 The modeling phase Input: The three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) . Procedure: (1) Construct the three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) and normalize it to a scaled two-way matrix X ( I × KJ ) along the batch-wise direction. Then, rearrange the matrix X ( I × KJ ) into a new two-way matrix X ( IK × J ) by means of the variable-wise unfolding. (2) Figure out the kernel matrix K utilizing the training dataset X ( IK × J ) , and further compute the kernel pseudo temporal variation matrix L k based on the dataset X ( IK × J ) and the reconstructed pseudo time series dataset T . (3) Set up the TBKSFA model on the basis of the kernel matrix K and the kernel time variation matrix L k according to (16), then figure out the generalized eigenvalue decomposition problem expressed in (17) to achieve the loading matrix A p . (4) Compute the statistics T 2 and SPE for the training dataset and apply the KDE method to determine the corresponding threshold values. Output: The threshold values of the statistics T 2 and SPE. 5.1.2 The monitoring phase Input: The test sample x te and the threshold values of the statistics T 2 and SPE. Procedure: (1) Collect the test sample x te and scale it using the training data, then calculate its test kernel vector k te . (2) Compute the values of statistics T 2 and SPE for x te according to (19) and (20). (3) Compare the values of statistics T 2 and SPE with the corresponding threshold values to detect the fault. Output: The operating status of the AHU system. 5.2 The KDSFA based fault diagnosis stage Input: The three-way training dataset X ( I × J × K ) , the recorded n s fault samples and the historical fault dataset H . Procedure: (1) Compute the average matrix X ‾ ( K × J ) of the three-way training dataset using (24) and construct the fault snapshot dataset S using the fault samples. (2) Calculate the kernel temporal variation matrix Δ K s of the fault snapshot dataset S , and compute the kernel inter-class pseudo temporal variation matrix Q K utilizing the average training dataset X ‾ ( K × J ) and the dataset S . (3) Establish the pairwise KDSFA model utilizing the matrices Δ K s and Q K according to (34), then solve the generalized eigenvalue decomposition problem in (35) to obtain the fault direction α S of the fault snapshot dataset S . (4) Extract the fault directions α i ( i = 1 , 2 , … , C ) of the C classes historical fault datasets by the pairwise KDSFA. Then, identify the fault pattern of the dataset S through measuring the similarities of its fault directions α S and the historical fault directions α i ( i = 1 , 2 , … , C ) according to (36). Output: The identified fault pattern of the fault snapshot dataset S . 6 Case study on the AHU system 6.1 Description of the AHU system datasets In our work, the proposed fault detection and diagnosis strategy is verified through the experimental data provided by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) research project No. RP-1312 [55]. A series of on-site experiments are performed in this project to simulate the dynamic properties of an AHU system which serves four zones under different environmental conditions. The normal and fault experimental data of this AHU system were recorded in the ASHRAE project No. RP-1312. More details on this project can be referred to [55,56]. As shown in Fig. 6 , the AHU-A and AHU-B utilized in the experiment are the identical AHUs. The AHU-A runs with different introduced faults, such as the damper and valve stuck as well as the duct leaking, to generate a variety of fault data, while the AHU-B runs normally to generate the normal operating data. Both AHU-A and AHU-B serve four zones denoted as Inner A & B, South A & B, West A & B and East A & B. The A and B zones have the same external thermal loads. In each experiment, the AHU system operated from 6: 00 to 18: 00 and halts from 18: 00 to 6: 00 in a running day. The normal and fault data in spring, summer and winter were measured and stored under the real outdoor weather conditions and indoor loads. As in [14,57], we select 16 important variables listed in Table 3 as the monitored variables. The physical meanings of the 16 monitored variables are also explained in Table 3. The monitored variables involve the AHU process variables, the values of the setting points, the actuators’ status and the controllers’ output signals. Considering the batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system in the long-term running period, the normal operating datasets N 1 ∼ N 13 stored for thirteen days are selected as the training datasets. Table 4 lists these thirteen normal operating batches and the corresponding collected time, which are used to build the three-way training dataset. The utilized fault patterns are shown in Table 5 , which contain the outdoor air damper stuck and the leaking, the heating coil valve leaking and the cooling coil valve stuck. The original experimental data were measured and recorded at 1 min interval, hence, each batch dataset of the AHU system has 1440 data points during one day running. To simplify the computation complexity, the experimental data are resampled at 3 min interval. Therefore, the numbers of the samples in the normal and fault batch datasets are both 480. Besides, Gaussian measurement noises are introduced to the monitored variables in the resampling phase. To verify the faut detection performance of the TBKSFA based approach, the tested fault batch datasets are reconstructed by using the first 120 samples the in normal dataset and the first 360 samples in the corresponding fault dataset. Note that, the normal dataset and the fault dataset are collected in the same day. In this way, the faults revealed in Table 5 are introduced to the tested fault batch datasets at the 121-th sample, and they last 360 samples. To identify the detected faults, the first 240 samples in fault dataset are used to construct the fault snapshot dataset S , while the rest samples in the fault dataset are viewed as the historical fault dataset H , for each fault pattern. 6.2 Training and fault datasets visualization by using the PCA As a typical linear dimensionality reduction algorithm, PCA converts the original process variables into some new uncorrelated latent variables arranged by their variances [48]. The principle components (PCs) of PCA are composed of the new latent variables with large variances in the principle component space. Therefore, the derived PCs have the capacity of representing the dominating changes of original process data. On the other hand, the original process variables projected in the residual space are regarded as the other new latent variables with small variances. Thus, these latent variables are deemed to contain noise information, and abnormal situations usually fall in the residual space. In brief, the original data input space is decomposed into two different subspaces by PCA, i.e., principle component space and residual space, in line with the data variations. More specifically, given an input matrix X ∈ R n × m with n samples and m process variables, the PCA decomposition is formulated as [48,58] (39) X = X ^ + X ∼ = ∑ i = 1 a t i p i T + X ∼ = T ^ P ^ + T ∼ P ∼ where X ^ indicates the reconstructed matrix of the PCs and X ∼ represents the residual matrix. t i ∈ R n is the i-th PC or score vector, p i ∈ R m indicates the i-th loading vector and a represents the number of the PCs projected in the principle component space. Besides, T ^ ∈ R n × a and P ^ ∈ R m × a are respectively the principal score matrix and corresponding loading matrix, while T ∼ ∈ R n × ( m - a ) and P ∼ ∈ R m × ( m - a ) represent the residual score matrix and corresponding loading matrix. The covariance matrix C PCA of the input matrix X is computed as (40) C PCA = 1 n - 1 X T X The principle loading matrix P ^ is constructed using the a eigenvectors of matrix C PCA which are corresponding to its a largest eigenvalues. Whereas, the residual loading matrix P ∼ is composed of the remaining eigenvectors of the matrix C PCA . In our work, a total of eleven fault patterns of the AHU system typical faults are employed to demonstrate the FDD performance of the proposed enhanced KSFA based approach. These eleven fault patterns can be further divided into three typical kinds of the AHU system faults, i.e., the outdoor air damper stuck, the heating coil valve leaking and the cooling coil value stuck. For the fault patterns belonging to the same kind of AHU typical fault, the only difference among them is the fault intensity. Therefore, six representative fault patterns F1, F3, F6, F8, F9 and F11 selected from the three typical AHU faults are visualized in low-dimension space by utilizing the PCA method. Besides, the average training dataset is also visualized with the aid of PCA. In order to achieve better results of data separation between the average training dataset and each representative fault pattern dataset, a total of 200 samples for each of the seven datasets are projected into the PCA principle component space and residual space. These used 200 samples are selected from the 151-th sample to the 350-th sample in each dataset. The data separation results of the seven datasets obtained in PCA two projection spaces are illustrated in Fig. 7 . According to Fig. 7(a), in PCA principle component space, the average training dataset is projected far away from the datasets of fault patterns F1, F9 and F11. And these three fault pattern datasets are also separated from each other clearly. Although the average training dataset can be isolated from the datasets of fault patterns F3, F5 and F8, the degree of isolation is not very obvious. Moreover, the projected datasets of fault patterns F3, F5, F8 and a small part of fault pattern F11 dataset are overlapped together, instead of being detached. On the contrary, much better data separation effectiveness is visualized in PCA residual space, as plotted in Fig. 7(b). It can be seen from Fig. 7(b) that the average training dataset is split apart from all the six fault pattern datasets clearly. Besides, these six fault pattern datasets are also placed far away from each other except for the overlapped datasets of fault patterns F3 and F6. 6.3 Comparative methods and parameter setting In this study, the fault detection feasibility and effectiveness of the TBKSFA based method is contrasted with the kernel SFA (KSFA), kernel locality preserving projections (KLPP) [36,37] and kernel PCA (KPCA) based methods. For the KSFA, KLPP and KPCA based approaches, the training dataset is constructed with only single normal batch dataset collected from one day instead of using multiply normal batch datasets gathered from several different days. For the TBKSFA based approach, the Gaussian kernel function is selected in accordance with [48,50,51]. In order to find optimal fault detection results of the training dataset, a grid search method [28,59,60] is utilized to select the Gaussian kernel parameter σ . Specifically, the kernel parameter σ is sought within the scope of {100, 200, … , 900, 1000}. Finally, the parameter σ is chosen as 300, while the number of the nearest neighbors l in the TBKSFA is empirically set to be 3. The Gaussian kernel function is also utilized in the KSFA, KLPP and KPCA based approaches, and the kernel parameters are all chosen to be 300 for fairness. Besides, in the KLPP based approach, the K-NN principle is used to construct the adjacency graph and the value of l is also set to be 3. In the TBKSFA, KSFA, KLPP and KPCA approaches, the principal components that possess at least the 95% contribution rate are retained. The threshold values of the statistics T 2 and SPE are computed in line with the 99% confidence level. After a fault is alerted, the fault diagnosis effectiveness of the KDSFA based similarity factor method is compared with the discriminant SFA (DSFA) based similarity factor method, the joint angle analysis (JAA) technique presented in [5,6] and the long short-term memory (LSTM) neural networks based fault diagnosis method [38–40]. For the KDSFA based method, the Gaussian kernel is utilized as the kernel function and the kernel parameter σ is set to be 10 by the grid search from {10, 20, … , 90, 100}. For the sake of fairness, the number of the nearest neighbors p is selected as 5 for the KDSFA and DSFA based methods according to our experience. Besides, both the KDSFA and DSFA are pairwisely applied to the average training dataset X ‾ and each fault dataset to extract the fault direction. To make a fair and convenient comparison, the similarity factor S P - JAA in the principal component space of the JAA technique is computed and used in this case study [35]. For the JAA technique, the number of the retained principal components is determined according to the 95% cumulative information contribution rate. For the LSTM based fault diagnosis approach, the eleven historical fault datasets H F 1 ∼ H F 11 are all used to train the LSTM classifier model. With the help of the cross validation, the number of hidden units in LSTM is set to be 500, the maximum number of training epochs is chosen as 300 and the size of the minimum batch in each training iteration is set to be 10. 6.4 The FDD performance evaluation indices To evaluate the fault detection performance of the KPCA, KLPP, KSFA and TBKSFA based approaches, two performance indices, i.e., the fault detection rate and the fault detection time, are utilized in this case study. The fault detection rate is defined as the percentage of the alarmed fault samples over the total fault samples. The fault is alarmed when three successive samples exceed the confidence limits. The fault detection time is considered as the first number of the earliest alarmed three successive fault samples. Higher fault detection rate and earlier fault detection time indicate much better fault detection performance. The details on the fault detection rate and fault detection time can be found in [28,61]. To estimate the fault diagnosis performance of the JAA, DSFA and KDSFA based similarity factor methods, the recognition error index (REI) and the recognition contrast degree (RCD) defined in Section 4.2 are employed. Smaller values of REI means better fault diagnosis performance, while larger value of RCD implies clearer and more convincing fault recognition result. The fault pattern identification accuracy rates can be achieved by employing the well-trained LSTM model to classify the eleven fault snapshot datasets S F 1 ∼ S F 11 . In our work, the similarity factors S KDSFA , S DSFA and S P - JAA are calculated as the similar degrees between the extracted fault directions of snapshot fault dataset and each historical fault dataset. Therefore, the LSTM’s fault pattern identification accuracy rate has different physical meaning compared with the defined three similarity factors. In order to compare the LSTM’s fault identification performance with that of the similarity factors S KDSFA , S DSFA and S P - JAA in a fair way, the REI of LSTM is further computed as: REI ( i ) = 1 - Accu ( i ) % 100 % , where REI ( i ) indicates the fault pattern recognition error of the i-th fault snapshot dataset and Accu ( i ) represents the corresponding identification accuracy. Obviously, the LSTM’s REI value is smaller, the fault pattern identification effectiveness is better. Because the output of the LSTM classifier is indeed the identification accuracy of each fault snapshot dataset, there is no need and no way to calculate the RCD index of the LSTM based method. 6.5 FDD performance comparison 6.5.1 The FDD performance comparison for fault F2 The fault detection charts of the TBKSFA, KSFA, KLPP and KPCA based methods for the fault F2 which involves the outdoor air damper stuck with 40% open at the 121-th sample are illustrated in Fig. 8 . The monitoring results of the KPCA in Fig. 8(a) show that the statistics T 2 and SPE can give an alarm of the fault F2 at the 123-th and 121-th samples, respectively. However, for the KPCA, the statistic T 2 has a low fault detection rate because a lot of fault samples go down below its alarm threshold after the 123-th sample. As plotted in Fig. 8(b), for the KLPP, its statistic T 2 gives better monitoring result compared with the KPCA, where the fault F2 is alerted at the 121-th sample and much fewer fault samples fall below the threshold value after the 121-th sample. Nevertheless, the statistic SPE of the KLPP achieves much worse fault detection result because many fault samples drop below the threshold value after the fault is detected at the 121-th sample. From Fig. 8(c), the statistic SPE of the KSFA illustrates better fault detection performance than the KLPP, which gives an alarm of the fault F2 at the 121-th sample with only a few missing alarmed fault samples. But, for the KSFA, the statistic T 2 gives an alarm of the fault F2 at the 121-th sample with much more missing alarmed fault samples. By comparing the monitoring results of these four methods, the TBKSFA gains the best fault detection effect in Fig. 8(d). From Fig. 8(d), the statistics T 2 and SPE of the TBKSFA both detect the fault F2 at the 121-th sample with no missing alarmed fault samples, which implies that the TBKSFA gives the earliest and the most accurate monitoring results. According to such monitoring results, the TBKSFA is the most effective one for detecting the fault F2 among these four fault detection approaches. The KDSFA and DSFA based similarity factor methods, the JAA based principal component space similarity factor S P - JAA and the LSTM based fault diagnosis method are further implemented to identify the pattern of the fault F2. In particular, after the fault snapshot dataset S F 2 is established using the detected fault samples, the fault pattern identification accuracy of LSTM for the dataset S F 2 is 79.16%. The similarity factors S KDSFA , S DSFA and S P - JAA between the dataset S F 2 and the eleven historical fault datasets H F 1 ∼ H F 11 are also estimated. As listed in Table 6 , these three similarity factors S KDSFA , S DSFA and S P - JAA between the datasets S F 2 and H F 2 are all the largest. Therefore, the snapshot dataset S F 2 is identified to be the identical fault pattern of the historical fault dataset H F 2 . Hence, the three methods all achieve the correct fault recognition results. Nevertheless, the three approaches have a big difference in other similarity factors. For instance, the similarity factors S P - JAA , S DSFA and S KDSFA between the dataset S F 2 and dataset H F 8 are respectively 0.7690, 0.3240 and 0.0270. As datasets S F 2 and H F 8 own different fault patterns, the similar degree between them is supposed to be as small as possible. Although the similarity factor S DSFA between these two datasets is smaller than the corresponding similarity factor S P - JAA , the similarity factors S P - JAA and S DSFA are still relatively large, which would result in some confusion. Instead, the similarity factor S KDSFA is only 0.0270, which is much smaller than the values of S P - JAA and S DSFA and can lead to much clearer discrimination. For a more intuitionistic analysis, the three similarity factors shown in Table 6 are illustrated in Fig. 9 . The quantized fault diagnosis comparisons of the JAA, DSFA, LSTM and KDSFA based approaches using the REI and RCD indices are listed in Table 7 . According to this table, the KDSFA based approach achieves the smallest REI value and the largest RCD value among the four approaches. Smaller REI value and larger RCD value can give better fault diagnosis performance. From Table 7, we can make the conclusion that the KDSFA based similarity factor is superior to the JAA and DSFA based similarity factors and the LSTM based fault diagnosis approach in terms of recognizing the fault pattern of the dataset S F 2 . 6.5.2 The FDD performance comparison for fault F5 The fault F5 which denotes the valve of heating coil leaking with 0.4 GPM is further applied to compare the fault detection effectiveness of the three methods. In Fig. 10 (a), the statistics T 2 and SPE of the KPCA alert the fault F5 at the 122-th sample and the 121-th sample, respectively. From Fig. 10(b), it can be seen that the statistic T 2 of the KLPP detects the fault F5 at the 123-th sample and the statistic SPE gives an alarm of the fault at the 241-th sample. However, the KPCA and KLPP based methods both result in low fault detection rates because many real fault samples are wrongly treated as the normal samples without giving fault alarms. On the contrary, the KSFA owns better monitoring performance as illustrated in Fig. 10(c), where its statistics T 2 and SPE detect the fault F5 at the 121-th sample simultaneously. To be specific, the statistic SPE of the KSFA achieves much higher fault detection rates because much fewer fault samples fall below the corresponding alarm thresholds after the 121-th sample. The fault detection charts of the TBKSFA in Fig. 10(d) indicate that both the statistics T 2 and SPE warn the fault F5 at the 121-th sample with the highest fault detection rates. Hence, the TBKSFA based approach is much more efficient to detect the fault F5 than the KPCA, KLPP and KSFA based approaches. When the fault F5 happens, the snapshot dataset S F 5 is established for diagnosing its fault pattern by utilizing the similarity factors S KDSFA , S DSFA , S P - JAA and the LSTM based method. For the LSTM based fault diagnosis method, the fault identification accuracy for the fault snapshot dataset S F 5 is 83.42%. Table 8 shows the similarity factors of the three methods. For the JAA based approach, the dataset S F 5 is correctly recognized as the fault pattern F5 because the S P - JAA value between the dataset S F 5 and the historical fault dataset H F 5 is the largest. However, the 1-st, 2-nd, 7-th, 8-th and 11-th S P - JAA values are all above 0.60, which raises the difficulty in clearly identifying the fault pattern. When the DSFA is applied, the fault recognition result is much better than that of the JAA based method. This is because not only the fault pattern of the dataset S F 5 is identified actually, but also the S DSFA values between the dataset S F 5 and the other historical fault datasets are all below 0.45. However, the S DSFA values still lead to an unimpressive result. In comparison with the JAA and the DSFA, the KDSFA reveals the most ideal fault identification result. The S KDSFA value between the datasets S F 5 and H F 5 is the largest, resulting in a correct diagnosis consequence. Other S KDSFA values are all less than 0.15, which is so small that it can guarantee the clearest identification result. The fault diagnosis performance of the four methods are evaluated by the REI and RCD again, and listed in Table 9 . We can find that the REI value of the JAA is the biggest which is 0.5482, and the RCD value of the JAA is the smallest which is 0.2155. This manifests that the diagnosis effectiveness of the JAA is the worst because it achieves the largest identification error and the lowest identification contrast.
