On the contrary, the DSFA achieves a smaller REI value and a bigger RCD value than that of the JAA. This reveals that the identification effect of the DSFA is better than that of JAA. The LSTM further obtains a better fault pattern diagnosis effect than that of the DSFA because its REI value is much smaller than the DSFA’s REI value. However, the improvement is still not satisfying. Furthermore, the KDSFA exhibits the best fault recognition performance with the smallest REI value (0.0759) and the biggest RCD value (0.8517), owing to its powerful capability to handle the nonlinear property and two-directional dynamics of the AHU system. 6.5.3 The FDD performance comparison for fault F10 Fig. 11 illustrates the fault detection results of the four approaches for the fault F10 which represents the valve of cooling coil stuck with partially 15% open. In Fig. 11(a), the statistic T 2 of the KPCA achieves the worst monitoring results, where the fault F10 is alerted at the 236-th sample with the lowest fault detection rates. Although the statistic SPE of the KPCA gives an alarm of fault F10 at the 121-th sample, many fault samples fluctuate around the alarm thresholds after the fault is detected. According to Fig. 11(b), the statistic T 2 of the KLPP brings an improved fault detection result, where the fault F10 is detected at the 121-th sample with much fewer missing alarmed fault samples. However, compared with the statistic SPE of the KPCA, the KLPP’s statistic SPE gains worse monitoring result because the fault F10 is alarmed at the 149-th sample and many real fault samples are wrongly treated as the normal samples. Being different from the fault detection results of the KPCA and the KLPP, Fig. 11(c) illustrates an improved monitoring results of the KSFA. According to Fig. 11(c), both the KSFA’s statistics T 2 and SPE exceed the corresponding alarm thresholds after the 121-th sample. Besides, owning to much fewer missing alarmed fault samples, the two statistics acquire much higher fault detection rates. In Fig. 11(d), both the statistics T 2 and SPE of the TBKSFA detect the fault F10 at the 121-th sample with no missing alarmed fault samples, which reacts more accurately and quickly to the fault F10 than the KPCA and KSFA based approaches. This manifests the superior effectiveness of the TBKSFA based method over the KPCA, KLPP and KSFA based methods. After the fault F10 is alerted, the KDSFA, DSFA and JAA based similarity factors and the LSTM based fault diagnosis method are also adopted to identify the pattern of the fault snapshot dataset S F 10 . Specifically, the fault identification accuracy of LSTM for the dataset S F 10 is calculated to be 86.08%. The computed values of the three similarity factors in this case are provided in Table 10 . From this table, the values of S P - JAA , S DSFA and S KDSFA between the fault snapshot dataset S F 10 and the historical fault dataset H F 10 are all the biggest. Therefore, these three methods all correctly recognize the dataset S F 10 as the same fault pattern of the dataset H F 10 . Nevertheless, the three approaches have different diagnosis performance when calculating the similarity factors for the other fault patterns. For instance, the JAA owns the S P - JAA values of 0.8197, 0.7936 and 0.8653 for the pairwise datasets S F 10 and H F 2 , S F 10 and H F 6 , S F 10 and H F 8 , respectively. The values are still so large that the difference between these fault patterns is thought to be not big. In contrast, the DSFA gives much more clear distinguishing identification results as the corresponding three values of S DSFA are 0.4716, 0.3534 and 0.4881. On the whole, the KDSFA exhibits the best recognition effectiveness owning to that the values of S KDSFA are decreased to be 0.0920, 0.0827 and 0.0320. As shown in Table 11 , the S DSFA acquires much smaller value in REI and much larger value in RCD than the S P - JAA . This implied that the identification effectiveness of the DSFA based approach is much better than that of the JAA based approach. Furthermore, the LSTM achieves a smaller REI value than that of the DSFA. It illustrates that the diagnosis effect of the LSTM is better than that of DSFA. However, the fault pattern identification performance is further improved by employing the KDSFA based method. The REI of the S KDSFA is the smallest with the value to be 0.0878 and the RCD of the S KDSFA is the largest with the value to be 0.8485. Again, this reveals the superiority of the KDSFA based method over the JAA and DSFA based methods when nonlinearly diagnosing the fault pattern. 6.5.4 The FDD performance comparison for the faults F1 ∼ F11 The fault detection performances of the KPCA, KLPP, KSFA and TBKSFA based methods for all the eleven faults F1 ∼ F11 are estimated, and shown in Tables 12 and 13 . All the tested eleven faults are indeed the step-change faults. Therefore, as listed in Table 12, the four approaches have the ability to detect most of the tested faults right after they are added to the AHU system at the 121-th sample. To be specific, the KPCA and KLPP based approaches result in some time delays to detect the faults F2, F3 and F5 ∼ F11, while they achieve no time delay to detect the other faults. Instead, the KSFA and TBKSFA based approaches gain almost no time delays to detect the faults F1 ∼ F11, which reveals much faster monitoring results than the KPCA and KLPP based approaches. However, on account of the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics of the AHU system, the four approaches achieve different fault detection rates as explained in Table 13. Due to the lack of capability to deal with the two-directional dynamics of the AHU system, the KPCA, the KLPP and the KSFA wrongly treat the real fault samples as the normal samples after the faults are detected. This would lead to much lower fault detection rates, especially for the statistic T 2 of the KPCA and the KSFA while for the statistic SPE of the KLPP. According to Table 13, both the statistics T 2 and SPE of the TBKSFA obtain almost the 100% fault detection rates to alert the faults F1 ∼ F11 by handling the two-directional dynamics of the AHU system, which are the highest among the four approaches. Furthermore, the fault detection rates of these three methods for the faults F1 ∼ F11 are averaged in Fig. 12 . Again, the visualized comparison revealed in Fig. 12 verifies the excellent fault detection effectiveness of the TBKSFA over the KPCA, KLPP and KSFA. After the faults F1 ∼ F11 have been detected, the three similarity factors S P - JAA , S DSFA , S KDSFA and the fault identification accuracy of the LSTM for the eleven fault snapshot datasets S F 1 ∼ S F 11 are computed. It turns out to be that all the JAA, DSFA and KDSFA based methods can identify the correct patterns of all the eleven fault snapshot datasets. To make further comparative analysis, the quantified recognition performance is evaluated by the REI and RCD indices. The values of REI and RCD are compared in Table 14 , where the best recognition performances are indicated in bold font. According to Table 14, the LSTM only has a slightly smaller REI values than that of the KDSFA for the two fault snapshot datasets S F 6 and S F 9 , while the KDSFA achieves the smallest REI values for the other nine fault snapshot datasets, and the KDSFA also obtains the largest RCD values for all the eleven snapshot datasets. Therefore, the REI and RCD indices given in Table 14 prove that the KDSFA owns the best fault diagnosis performance among these four methods again. 7 Conclusions A novel enhanced kernel SFA based FDD strategy is presented to detect and diagnose the AHU system faults in this paper. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first time to regard the AHU system as a special batch control process due to its operating characteristics. Our work has the other two contributions. Firstly, a TBKSFA algorithm is developed to dispose of the two-directional dynamic characteristics and to nonlinearly capture the underlying driving forces of the AHU system. Specifically, the multiway data analysis approach is adopted to cope with the batch-wise dynamics among multiple batch runs, and the time-wise kernel SFA model is then employed to mine the time-wise dynamic and the nonlinear properties in a batch run. Secondly, a tough problem of nonlinearly diagnosing the fault pattern is addressed. By integrating the discriminant analysis technique into the kernel SFA, the pairwise KDSFA model is further developed to extract the fault direction that separates the normal dataset and each fault dataset optimally. The pattern of the fault snapshot dataset is nonlinearly discerned through computing the similarities of its fault direction and the historical fault directions. Through the detailed comparisons with the traditional KPCA, the closely related KSFA and the emerging KLPP based monitoring methods, the experiments have verified the superior fault detection effectiveness of the proposed TBKSFA based approach. Besides, by comparing with the conventional JAA and the strongly linked DSFA based similarity factors as well as the the rising LSTM based fault diagnosis method comprehensively, the case study also confirms the outstanding performance of the developed KDSFA based similarity factor approach for nonlinearly identifying the fault pattern. Due to the operating characteristics of the HVAC system, the other important components such as the chiller system and the variable refrigerant flow (VRF) system, also exhibit the time-wise and batch-wise dynamic properties. Thus, except for the AHU system, the proposed enhanced kernel SFA based FDD strategy can also be applied to these vital components of the HVAC system. As aforementioned, the AHU system evolves into multiple operating modes in a batch running because of the time-wise dynamics. In our future study, we will investigate other modified kernel SFA models to reveal and utilize the information of multiplicity in multiple operating modes, and to further improve the fault detection performance for the AHU system. Moreover, in order to enhance the fault diagnosis effectiveness, our future work will be carried out to use the extracted slow features as the inputs of some artificial intelligence based classification methods. coredata.dc:description: Air handling unit (AHU) is a typical special batch control process, exhibiting strong nonlinear property and two-directional dynamic characteristics which are the time-wise and batch-wise dynamic characteristics. Specifically, the time-wise dynamic characteristic corresponds to the evolution of different operating modes caused by the underlying driving forces which vary slowly in each running day (a batch run), while the batch-wise dynamic characteristic relates to the dynamic variations and deviations among different running days (batch runs). In order to further improve the AHU FDD performance through capturing the underlying driving forces of the AHU system and tackling the batch-wise dynamic property between different batch runs, in this paper, an enhanced kernel slow feature analysis (SFA) based FDD scheme is developed to detect and identify the faults of the nonlinear AHU system. Firstly, a three-way data based kernel SFA (TBKSFA) approach is proposed to detect the faults. In the proposed TBKSFA approach, the kernel trick is adopted in the SFA to sufficiently deal with the nonlinearity and the time-wise dynamic characteristic, and the multiway data analysis is employed to cope with the batch-wise dynamics among different batch runs by converting the three-way training dataset into a variable-wise unfolding two-way matrix. In addition, to handle the tough problem of nonlinearly identifying the fault pattern, a novel kernel discriminant SFA (KDSFA) model is further built by combining the kernel SFA with the discriminant analysis method. In the fault pattern diagnosis process, the proposed KDSFA is pairwisely implemented on the normal and fault datasets to calculate the fault direction, and the fault is then identified by computing the similar degrees of its own fault direction and the historical fault directions. At last, experiments and comparisons on the FDD performance of the developed approach are made using the experimental data provided by ASHRAE Research Project RP-1312. To be specific, the proposed TBKSFA based fault detection method is compared with the popular kernel principal component analysis (KPCA) method, the closely related kernel SFA method and the emerging manifold learning based kernel locality preserving projections (KLPP) method. While the developed KDSFA based fault pattern diagnosis scheme is compared with the conventional jointed angle analysis technique, the strongly linked DSFA based method and the rising artificial neural networks based long short-term memory(LSTM) classifier. Experimental results demonstrate that significant improvements can be achieved by the proposed approach compared with some other popular methods.
coredata.dc:title: Fault detection and diagnosis of the air handling unit via an enhanced kernel slow feature analysis approach considering the time-wise and batch-wise dynamics
